verses.text: So the heavens and the earth and all their array were completed.
verses.comment: This verse marks the completion of creation, emphasizing God's creative act as finished and perfect, a theme found throughout scripture. It subtly echoes the order and structure often recognized in both the natural world and liturgical worship.

verses.text: By the seventh day God finished His work which He had done, and He rested on the seventh day from all His work that He had made.
verses.comment: God's rest on the seventh day lays the pattern for the Sabbath, foreshadowing both spiritual rest and the sacred rhythm of worship. There are echoes here of entering into God's rest through faith in Christ (see Heb. 4:4).

verses.text: God blessed the seventh day and made it holy, because on it He rested from all His work that He had done in creation.
verses.comment: The sanctification of the seventh day sets up the idea of sacred time. The sanctity of certain days leads organically to ongoing liturgical practices in Christian tradition.

verses.text: These are the generations of the heavens and the earth when they were created, in the day that the LORD God made earth and heavens.
verses.comment: The phrase 'these are the generations' signals a new section. The name 'LORD God' (YHWH Elohim) introduces God's personal covenantal nature, which will deepen through salvation history.

verses.text: No bush of the field was yet in the land, and no plant of the field had yet sprung up; for the LORD God had not sent rain on the land, and there was no man to work the ground.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the interdependence between creation and humanity, hinting at the future vocation of mankind in caring for creation, a stewardship role that echoes throughout scripture.

verses.text: Yet a mist would rise from the earth and water the whole surface of the ground.
verses.comment: This suggests a pre-rain irrigation, reflecting order and provision. Some ancient traditions see this as a symbol of sacramental blessing, God's grace poured out on the earth.

verses.text: Then the LORD God formed man from the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and man became a living being.
verses.comment: God's personal involvement in creating man sets humanity apart. The 'breath of life' prefigures God's Spirit (see 1 Cor. 15:45), linking physical and spiritual life—anticipating the renewal found in Christ through the Spirit.

verses.text: The LORD God planted a garden in Eden, in the east, and there He placed the man whom He had formed.
verses.comment: The garden is described as a place of communion, foreshadowing the spiritual realities of paradise and divine fellowship seen later in scripture.

verses.text: And out of the ground the LORD God made to grow every tree that is pleasant to the sight and good for food. The tree of life was in the middle of the garden, and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil.
verses.comment: Life and knowledge are central motifs, with the tree of life prefiguring eternal life offered in Christ (Rev. 2:7), and the tree of knowledge representing moral agency and the possibility of sin.

verses.text: A river flows out of Eden to water the garden, and from there it divides and becomes four rivers.
verses.comment: The river is a sign of abundance and blessing, often interpreted as a symbol of life and grace flowing from God, connecting to visions of living water found in Ezekiel and Revelation.

verses.text: The name of the first is Pishon; it is the one that flows around the whole land of Havilah, where there is gold.
verses.comment: The inclusion of gold and precious stones in the context of Eden carries hints toward later themes of sacred space, such as the tabernacle and temple worship.

verses.text: And the gold of that land is good; bdellium and onyx stone are there.
verses.comment: References to precious materials link creation to sanctuary imagery, later seen in the priestly garments and temple, pointing to the sacredness of creation and worship.

verses.text: The name of the second river is Gihon; it flows around the whole land of Cush.
verses.comment: Later scriptural mentions of Gihon connect the narrative to Jerusalem, signifying God's ongoing provision to His people and the centrality of sacred geography.

verses.text: The name of the third river is Tigris, which flows east of Assyria. And the fourth river is the Euphrates.
verses.comment: By naming these rivers, the passage situates Eden within real geography, underscoring both physical and spiritual realities in scripture.

verses.text: The LORD God took the man and put him in the garden of Eden to work it and keep it.
verses.comment: The vocation of man to 'work and keep' the garden mirrors priestly duties of service and guardianship, prefiguring humanity's role in sacred worship and liturgy.

verses.text: And the LORD God commanded the man, saying, 'You may freely eat from every tree of the garden,'
verses.comment: God's commandment sets up the principle of obedient freedom, the foundation of covenant relationship that is fulfilled through faith and grace in scripture.

verses.text: But from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, you must not eat, for in the day that you eat from it you will surely die.
verses.comment: God warns of spiritual death as a consequence of disobedience, prefiguring the doctrine of original sin and the necessity of grace—culminating in redemption through Christ.

verses.text: Then the LORD God said, 'It is not good that the man should be alone; I will make a helper suitable for him.'
verses.comment: The creation of a helper reveals the social nature of humanity and the importance of complementarity and unity, prefiguring the relational aspects of the Christian community.

verses.text: Out of the ground the LORD God formed every beast of the field and every bird of the heavens and brought them to the man to see what he would call them. Whatever the man called each living creature, that was its name.
verses.comment: Naming the animals shows human authority and stewardship. It hints at mankind's priestly dignity and responsibility within creation.

verses.text: The man gave names to all livestock, to the birds of the heavens, and to every beast of the field. But for the man there was not found a helper suitable for him.
verses.comment: Despite his authority, Adam's solitude was not complete without companionship, foreshadowing the deeper unity found in marriage and ultimately in Christ and His Church.

verses.text: So the LORD God caused a deep sleep to fall upon the man, and while he slept He took one of his ribs and closed up its place with flesh.
verses.comment: God's creative act here is intimate. Ancient interpreters saw Adam's sleep as a foreshadowing of death and rebirth, prefiguring Christ's sacrifice and the new creation.

verses.text: And the rib that the LORD God had taken from the man He made into a woman and brought her to the man.
verses.comment: The woman is formed from the man—indicating equality, complementarity, and the foundation of sacramental marriage. This foreshadows the unity of Christ and His people.

verses.text: Then the man said, 'This is now bone of my bones and flesh of my flesh; she shall be called Woman, because she was taken out of Man.'
verses.comment: Adam's exclamation expresses profound union and equality, echoing the later spiritual mysteries of Christian marriage (Eph. 5:32).

verses.text: Therefore a man shall leave his father and his mother and hold fast to his wife, and they shall become one flesh.
verses.comment: Marriage is divinely instituted as a union of man and woman, a mystery that is elevated in Christian teaching as a sign of Christ's unity with the Church (Eph. 5:31-32).

verses.text: And the man and his wife were both naked and were not ashamed.
verses.comment: Their innocence points to the original harmony with God and creation, a state lost in the fall but ultimately restored through grace and redemption, central to the story of salvation.
